WATER SITUATION
(Statement by the Prime Minister)


2.34 p.m.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the statement I wish to make to the House is in respect of the water situation.

    With the belated break of the North-East Monsoon, hon. Members would like to know the present water situation and the outlook - whether and when rationing can be lifted. The total stocks in impounding reservoirs today, 16th December, are around 2,780 million gallons or 47.1 per cent of the total. The corresponding figure on the same date, 16th December, last year was 68.6 per cent or 4,050 million gallons in impounding reservoirs.

    The rainfall to-date in Singapore taking the readings of Peirce Reservoir shows 62 inches as against the yearly average of 100 inches. In Johore in the Tebrau area the rainfall up to date has been 81 inches as against a yearly average of 108 inches.

Column: 644



    Members will notice that rainfall figures up to date have been about 38 per cent below average in Singapore and 25 per cent below average in Johore.

    Members will have noted a considerable amount of attention in all the language newspapers about water rationing, coinciding with a recurrence of the cholera epidemic. A number of people have taken the trouble to write to the newspapers urging the abolition of water rationing as one of the means to combat the cholera epidemic.

    The Public Utilities Board has given this matter urgent consideration. They have been in consultation with the medical officers of the Health Ministry. The Health Ministry is of the view that move, the present El Tor cholera epidemic has Order not been brought about so much by drought conditions in Singapore resulting in water rationing, but more by the higher incidence of human carriers of cholera. A complete de-rationing may lead to a much more dangerous condition if there should be a drought next made year.

    Sir, there has been a relaxation of two hours per day with water supply stopped at 10 a.m. instead of 8 a.m. in order to allow the City area to be flushed clean more thoroughly at least once a week. This change adds to the daily consumption of water by about 150,000 gallons.

    Water rationing has to be continued until the safety level in our water stocks has been reached. Members may like to know what is the safety level of water stocks. This varies at different times of the year. The level should be such as to see us, at an average daily consumption, now of about 75 million gallons per day, through the annually expected dry months of June to September to the next wet season.

    At the time we lifted rationing at the end of January 1962 after the 1961 drought, the stocks were at 67.5 per cent or nearly 4,000 million gallons. To see ourselves safely through the next dry season between June and September, there should be more than 60 per cent of water stocks in our reservoirs by the end of the North-East Monsoon in January.

Column: 645



    At present the stocks are only 47.1 per cent and I regret to say that rationing will have to continue until it reaches 60 per cent, we hope, by the end of the rainy season. However, the forecast by the Meteorological Office has not been optimistic and less than average December rainfall has been forecast.

    The position will be reviewed at the end of January, and at the review, consideration will be taken of the Scudai supplies expected in June next year a which would produce another 10-15 -million gallons per day in conditions of drought and 25-30 million gallons per day normally.

(Total number on 30-11-63)

TOTAL NUMBER OF REGISTERED UNEMPLOYED ON 30-11-63


    2. Mr Kow Kee Seng asked the Minister for Labour what was the total

Column: 646

number of registered unemployed on 30th November, 1963 or at the latest available date.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the total number of persons registered and actively seeking employment assistance from the Employment Exchange was 40,534 on 30th November, 1963. Not all of them are totally unemployed. There are many on casual part-time or full-time employment among these registrants who are seeking better employment.

    I also have to point out that whilst the Government is doing everything to reduce the number of unemployed through its industrialisation programmes, the Barisan Sosialis is doing everything to increase the number by sabotaging these programmes. In fact, the Barisan Sosialis has contributed much to the unemployed figures. More than 1,800 workers were forced into unemployment through the irresponsible and unreasonable strikes created by the Barisan trade unions in the past two years.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, these are the people who are constantly and deliberately causing misery, hardship and unhappiness to the workers, and now they say they are concerned over the unemployment situation. This is just shedding crocodile tears or, as the Chinese saying goes, "the cat pretending to mourn for the death of the mouse."

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE


    3. Mr Ong Lian Teng asked the Minister for Social Affairs how many persons received public assistance as at 30th November, 1963.

GEYLANG FIRES
(Government aid to victims)


    4. Mr Ong Lian Teng asked the Minister for Social Affairs what was the total amount of aid in cash received up to 30th November, 1963, by each fire victim of the recent fires in Lorongs 3 and 21, Geylang, and what other aids in kind has the Government given to each of the fire victims.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, I have been asked by the Minister to reply to Question No. 4.

    Victims of the Geylang, Lorong 21, fire which occurred on 29th October, 1963, have received total assistance in cash of $40 each. Victims of the Geylang, Lorong 5-9, fire of 15th November, 1963, have so far each received $40 aid in cash.

    In addition to these payments, families which have lost all their possessions as a result of the two fires will be paid rent subsidy, calculated at $7 per victim, subject to a maximum of $35 per month per family, for a period of three months. Victims of the Lorong 21 fire were also given one tin of condensed milk per person from stocks of previous donations in kind which had been received from the public in respect of previous fires. For the Lorong 5-9 fire, donations of condensed milk, rice and noodles were received from the public, and were distributed to the victims as follows: 

                             Condensed milk       1 tin per person

                             Rice                 3 katies per person

                             Noodles              1 lb. per person
Old clothing donated by members of the public was also distributed to victims of both fires.

KOVAN ROAD
(Road metalling and installation of street lights)


    5. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether the policy is to metal a road and install street lighting at the same time (b) whether he is aware that

Column: 648

Kovan Road is metalled but has no street lights; and (c) when will street lights be installed in Kovan Road.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Ho Cheng Choon) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked by the Minister for National Development to answer the question.

    (a) Yes. It is the present policy to metal a road and install street lighting at the same time. I should add that with the coming into force of the Local Government Integration Ordinance on 1st September, 1963, when a private road is made up to Government's specifications, the owners of frontages will have to pay for the road as well as for the cost of providing street lights.

    (b) Kovan Road was made up under the provisions of section 133 of the Municipal Ordinance which did not require a road to be metalled and lighted at the same time. Street lights are provided according to priority. Priority is normally given to areas where schools are sited or where accidents occur frequently.

    (c) That part of Kovan Road from its junction with Yio Chu Kang Road to Hillside Drive has already been lighted. It received priority because of the existence of three schools. The lighting of the remainder of Kovan Road at an estimated cost of $13,000 is under consideration.

SURIN AVENUE
(Supply of electricity)


    6. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he is aware that residents of Surin Avenue have made repeated requests for the supply of electricity and that they have sent a petition to the Prime Minister; (b) whether he is aware that electric wires were left there early this year but nothing further has happened (c) whether he could indicate when the work will proceed; and (d) whether the electricity could be supplied by Christmas.

Column: 649



    Mr Ho Cheng Choon (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, (a) the scheme for the supply of electricity to Surin Avenue and Charlton Lane was approved towards the end of 1962 and work was put in hand in early March 1963.

    (b) Due to objections raised by the owners of the land through a legal firm, work was suspended at the end of March 1963. Legal opinion was sought from the State Advocate-General and, acting on his advice, the owners' solicitors were advised that work was to be recommenced. The ownership of the land has now changed hands, and a notice has been served on the new owner, informing him that work will recommence.

    (c) Work will recommence before the end of the year.

    (d) It is hoped that houses will have electricity supplied in early 1964.

    Head D7 -

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D7 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 1.

    Mr Speaker, I merely wish to know from the Prime Minister whether this vote includes the purchasing of land at Kampong Eunos, Jalan Ladang, Jalan

Ang Teng and Jalan Eunos for the purpose of building community centres in these places, as he has announced during his visit to Kampong Kembangan lately.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, may I first clarify the purpose of this particular development vote? The provision envisages expenditure under the following categories:

    (1) Prompt acquisition of fire site.

    (2) The purchase of land excess of actual areas required for a specific project in circumstances which reduce the overall cost of acquisition.

    (3) Taking up of surplus land held under title and offered by the United Kingdom Armed Services.

    (4) The acquisition of large areas of vacant private land ripe for development whose availability in the open market is known in advance,

    (5) Expected and foreseen expenditure by each particular Ministry for development purposes includes the purchase of land required for development projects. The matter that has been raised by the Member for Kampong Kembangan strictly relates to the development vote under Social Affairs. However, whilst I am unable to give him an undertaking now on the details of the request for community centres which will entail acquisition of land in Kampong Eunos, Jalan Ladang, Jalan Ang Teng and Jalan Eunos, I can say that it is the policy to site the community centre in the rural areas most convenient from the population point of view with regard to transport and rural tracks and footpaths. In the specific instances that he has in mind, the situation is being studied with regard to the community centres already erected, and should a case be made out for more centres near where the concentration

of population in the kampongs is now sited, acquisition of the various pieces of land indicated by the petitioners will be considered.

    Mr Chia Thye Poh (Jurong)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, we can see that the provision amounting to $10,700,000 in respect of the Government's policy of land acquisition for development purposes is quite a large sum of money. But judging from the achievements during these few years and up to the end of 1963, we see that the sum spent on acquisition is only $1,450,000. In other words, the sum for the acquisition of land for next year has been greatly increased. We can also see from the other heads in the Development Estimates that there is provision for land acquisition for development purposes. I do not know whether, when drafting these Estimates, the Government have considered the necessity for such a large sum of money for land acquisition.

    Another question I would like to ask is how the price for land acquisition is fixed. Is it based on the price obtained in January 1961? Not long ago we read in the newspapers that there was a piece of land in Jurong amounting to 1,020 acres belonging to a foreign company - Bajau Rubber and Produce Estate Company. This is owned by big foreign capitalists. As a result of the development of the Jurong industrial site, the value of that piece of land has increased very greatly. In other words, the Government have used public money, through taxation, to develop the Jurong industrial site. As a result, the value of the land in this area has increased. This will only benefit such foreign capitalists as the Bajau Rubber and Produce Estate Company. This has enabled this particular company to make a profit of $8 million. According to the market price, the price of land should not be more than $1,000 per acre in that area. If the Government are really sincere in wanting to look after the interest and welfare of the people, then it should not use public money to develop land in such a way that in the end it is the foreign

Column: 652

capitalists who benefit. I do not know what measures the Government will take in regard to this particular land.

    The Government have also acquired land from the Hokkien Huay Kuan. The price paid to them at that time was very low. It was about $1,000 per acre, as I have just now mentioned. But what price do the Government intend to offer for this particular piece of land owned by a foreign capitalist? Is it a high price? How? Or will the Government allow the price of land to increase so that it will get higher and higher in the course of time. I hope the P.A.P. will not try to do things in such a way that in the end it is the foreign capitalists who will benefit.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, those of us who are new in this Assembly will soon have to get ourselves accustomed to the regular drivel that is churned out by the ghost writers and the mentors on the other side.

3.00 p.m.

    The Member's last point, if I may take it first. The implication is that here is a Government which goes out of its way, either willingly or stupidly, to assist foreign capitalists and who treats its own capitalists harshly. He referred to what has already been printed in some political journal of the Barisan Sosialis about the Bajau Land Company.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to take advantage of the mathematical virtues of the Member for Jurong at some stage in this session of the House when a Bill with regard to land acquisition and development charges is raised before this Assembly. We are not concerned with whether the land belongs to European capitalists or local capitalists. We are concerned to see that no private land owner benefits as a result of capital expenditure made by the Government - the building of roads, the laying of services, water, gas, electricity, railroads and, in any case, the general increase in the price of land, because land is limited and population increases. The amount of currency increases with the population increase and the increase in wealth;

Column: 653

but land does not. All over the world, this is a problem which is faced in all growing communities. Of course, if we were a community falling backwards and land values collapsed, and population dispersed into the hinterland of Malaysia, then different considerations would apply.

    I want to put to the Member for Jurong certain broad principles which we are trying to apply in a Bill which we shall introduce in this House. The first principle is that nobody should get a windfall because of development at public expense.

    The second principle is that whenever land is required for a public purpose, the price to be paid for that land should not be higher than what it would have been worth had the Government not contemplated development generally in that area.

    With these two principles, we are then faced with a constitutional difficulty in that, in the Constitution of Malaysia, there is a provision which says that no land or property can be acquired or requisitioned by the State without adequate compensation being paid, and one has to reconcile the two broad principles I have enunciated, namely, that nobody should benefit as a result of government expenditure and development; and secondly, the principle enunciated in the Constitution. This is a highly complex matter. I am quite sure the Member for Jurong, if he is sincere, will spend some time in Select Committee in working out an ingenious way whereby concerns like the Bajau Land Company, or whatever realty company, does not profit at the expense of the people of Singapore.

    If the Member is interested in real estate values, one of the ways in which it is possible to control land values is that suggested by my Chief Planner, that land should no longer be freehold and that all land should be leasehold, say, for 66 years or 99 years. So that at the lapse of every 66th or 99th year, as the case may be, the land reverts completely in toto to the State and is then again sold or otherwise disposed of to the public. That is one of the techniques which we could employ.

Column: 654



    There are certain difficulties as to how and what development charges should be apportioned. One develops Jurong at the cost of several million dollars. How does one apportion the development costs against all the contiguous frontages? The people who own land around the area will naturally profit because the whole of that area becomes a developed area. Certain schemes have been tried in Britain unsuccessfully and have been abandoned. We are studying other schemes which are in operation in Australia, where the technique of the short-term lease has been employed. But the disadvantage there is that nobody builds any house worth while because the land very soon reverts back to the State. Somehow between these two we have to strike a happy mean. But I would like to assure the House that it is our intention to see that no private owner benefits out of public expenditure on land. That is the first principle.

    When the legislation is passed, it will have retrospective effect.

    Sir, as to the price that will be paid, the reason why we have increased the sum to $10 million is that there is a contingency of several large purchases for the coming year. We are sanguine enough to believe that after the exposure that the Barisan Sosialis suffered at the hands of the electorate in September this year, they will find it more difficult to try to block our resettlement schemes. There is also a resettlement scheme which the Minister for National Development will soon be announcing, generous terms of cash payments or substitution in kind. That is because we are sanguine enough to hope that - whatever may happen in two or three years' time as the situation develops and the Barisan become more skilful in their techniques of blocking development - they will have considerable difficulty. One, because of the generous terms which we will be offering, and, secondly, the fact that they are suffering from a nervous feeling that they will not be so successful in preventing our redevelopment projects. The price of the development in most of these cases - the

Column: 655

market value as at the time of acquisition - will have to be taken into consideration during the passage of this Bill.

Ariff Bin Suradi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, in connection with the loans to the Housing and Development Board, I believe the programmes implemented by the Housing Board cannot be denied by anyone, that the Board has used these loans to the best advantage and thousands of flats have been built quickly. 3.15 p.m.

    The Housing Board scheme to sell flats to the occupiers is a novel scheme for the lower income group so that they may own these fiats, as has been stated in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech.

    So I hope the Minister in charge will explain to the House when such a scheme will be implemented and the areas in which work will be started, so that the occupiers of flats will be able to make the necessary preparations for the purchase of such flats.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, first I will answer the Member of the Opposition as regards loans to the Housing Board. I will say that the rate of interest charged by the Government is an effective rate: that is, if the interest on loans in the market is about 5� or 5� per cent, the Housing Board will be charged accordingly.

Column: 657



    On his next question - what do the Government do with the rate of interest that is charged to the Housing Board? I will say this, that the Government will have to raise loans also from the market for their development projects. Therefore, these interest rates are in payment for the loans which the Government raise in the market in order to lend to the Housing Board.

    The next question is: how many one-room flats are completed? Our Five-Year programme calls for the completion of 51,000 units of flats. We know that the people of Singapore have various rates of income: some of them earn $100, $200, $300 up to $800 a month, or some of them are millionaires. Therefore, in our building programme, we take into account tenants in different categories of income and we work it out so that 30 per cent of our programme will be for a one-room unit, 30 per cent of the units built will be for a two-room unit, and 40 per cent will be for a three-room unit. Now it is usual all over the world for housing authorities to calculate on the basis that a family or wage-earner should set aside between 20 and 25 per cent of his income as rental. Therefore, our flats cater for people with an income of as low as $100 a month, because 20 per cent of $100 is $20 and that is the rent of a one-room unit. Last year, we completed about 12,000 units and out of that 3,000 are one-room units.

    As for the number of vacant Housing Board flats, at the moment it stands at 2.87 per cent of about 40,000 units that are under our control.

    Now to come to the question raised by one of our Back-benchers with regard to the selling of houses. We are looking into this question now because it involves pricing, terms of payment, and, most important of all, the maintenance of and titles to these units when we sell. There is a team looking into it and I expect to be able to make an announcement after it has made its findings and recommendations with regard to the selling of houses built by the Housing and Development Board.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to add to what our Minister has said just now.

The experts also say that no one can build cheaper flats than those built. These flats are built to suit the various lower income groups. They are offered to the people at rentals of $20, $40 and $60 per month in respect of one-room, two-room and three-room flats.

    At present, I understand there are no more one-room flats. We had a few thousand of them, and since there has been such a great demand, we have to build several thousand one-room units at the Redhill industrial site.

    We now have only 2.87 per cent of flats vacant and this is considered by building experts to be a very small figure. This is because the people pick and choose the flats.

    Now I have this to say. The Communists always exploit the poor because in a prosperous community Communism will not survive. This is a lesson the Barisan Sosialis must always learn and not forget.

    Mr Chio Cheng Thun(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, there are several points on which I am not clear and I would like the Minister to explain them. The Minister says that the rate of interest charged is 5.75 per cent. I would like to know the total sum involved on this rate of interest.

    There are 2.87 per cent of flats vacant, I would like to know the actual number of such vacant flats.

    Another point is this. Are the Government still building flats in spite of the fact that there are these vacant flats? Are the Government still contemplating flats with monthly rentals of $20?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, if I understand the Member for Choa Chu Kang correctly, he wants to know the total amount we have paid out in interest. Well, this loan is a loan for 60 years.
